Blog.post: Gestern Nacht war ich auf meiner ersten Canberra-Party; es war sehr langweilig, die Stimmung unterkuehlt und eine Menge komische Menschen dort, dafuer gabs gute Fruehlingsrollen und ich hatte eine Menge Spass mit meinen Maedels. Wusstet ihr, dass President Truman zur Atombombe, die Amerika so mir nichts dir nichts ueber Hiroshima abwarf, Folgendes zu sagen hatte: "The world will note that the first atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima, a military base. That was because we wished in this first attack to avoid, insofar as possible, the killing of civilians"? Ca 363.656 Menschen waren vom Abwurf der Atombombe betroffen. Nach sechs Monaten waren 78.150 Japaner an den Folgen gestorben. Ca 13% der Menschen, die sich zum Zeitpunkt des Bombenabwurfs in der Stadt befanden waren japanische Truppen. Wusstet ihr ausserdem, dass nachdem der Schaden angerichtet war, die Amerikaner argumentierten, der willkuerliche Angriff auf Pearl Harbour sei ja wohl etwas, woran man sich erinnern solle, bevor man die Benutzung der Atombombe in Hiroshima und Nagasaki in Frage stelle? 1,178 Menschen wurden in Pearl Harbour verletzt, 2.403 starben. 68 davon waren Zivilisten.

Woher kommt eigentlich der Titel "boxing day"?! Gestern mittag, als ich mir mein Mittagessen zwischen die Kiemen drueckte und mit Wehmut an das letzte Silvester dachte, als ich frierend und die Arme voll mit diversen Palstiktueten meine drei Glaeser Sekt kippte, fiel es mir wie Schuppen von den Augen: Boxing day macht keinen Sinn! Noch nicht. Es sollte ja die ein oder andere Erklaerung geben, warum zur Hoelle der erste Tag des Jahres dermassen ruede betitelt wird. Da mein Zustand am Ersten seit einigen Jahren immer einem "Geboxten" gleichkommt, koennte darin schon die Loesung liegen, aber unsereins kennt keinen Schmerz und scheut keine Muehe, den variablen Alternativen hinterher zu jagen, demnaechst also mehr. Ausserdem musste ich heute einmal mehr zu meiner deutschen Ueberraschung feststellen, wie ernst man Gesetze bzw einfache Verbote und Richtlinien in Australien so nimmt. Da geht man selbstbewusst querfeldein, flugs vorbei am "trespassers will be prosecuted"-Schild, das maechtig und dunkel seinen Mann steht; "not entry" bruellt es in rot auf weiss und pfeifend geht man seiner Wege, direkt durch die schildbestueckte Tuer und fragt die naechstbeste Person in diesem Korridor, wie man denn bitte wohin kommt und die oder der schert sich auch nicht im Geringsten um die verbotene Anwesenheit sondern dirigiert freundlich laechelnd weiter. Im Supermarkt dann wird der mit zu wenig Geld bestueckte Kunde mit einem "no worries" beglueckt und geht halt weniger bezahlend heim und bei einer Polizeikontrolle auf der Strasse loechert man mich strahlend, wies mir denn bisher so gefaellt, in Australien, waehrend mich ein Drogenhund beschnueffelt und eine Polizistin meine Tasche durchwuehlt. Anschliessend dann wuenschen sie mir noch jede Menge Spass. In der Schule dann, direkt unterm "no smoking" Schild, ist kein Boden mehr, vor Filtern -aber das teilen die Australier wohl mit einem Grossteil der Schulen in anderen Laendern. Wenigstens das beruhigt. Kein Land ist wie das andere, sagt man, ganz sicher aber ist kein Land wie Australien. Von wegen oelige Straende und alte Autoreifen in toedlicher Hitze! Hier findet man tote Kaenguruhs auf dem Gehweg (die auf ominoese Art und Weise verschwinden), friert nachts bei minus 7 Grad Celsius und bekommt ellenlange Forschungsprojekte um die Ohren geknallt! Ich hoffe ihr beneidet mich.

Heute morgen, als ich einmal mehr todesmutig die Limestone Avenue entlang trottete, fiel es mir ploetzlich wie Schuppen von den Augen: Lucy ist weg und hinterliess einen Streifen platt gedrueckte braeunlich-graue Grashalme, die nun traurig im Wind pfeifen. Ich sage euch, man haette einen Western drehen koennen.. So bitter-suess angeregt ging ich also meiner Wege um gleich-nur ein paar Stunden spaeter- ueber die Schoepfungsgeschichte zu stolpern. Beim Lesen der Gensis fielen mir so der ein oder andere Punkt auf, der mich doch im Stil irgendwie an Bush erinnerte, so wahnwitzig das nun klingen mag. Nicht nur ist das Ganze idiotensicher ("und er sah, dass es gut war" "und es war gut" "und es war so", alle paar Saetze; so dass die guten Christen, wenn schon nicht vollstaendig fluessig, alle paar Saetze was zum Mitgroehlen haben) , neinneinnein, man findet auch das ein oder andere Zitast, ueber dem man wahrhaftig vor Lachen in Traenen ausbrechen koennte; so zB, wenn Adam und Eva die ganze Zeit nackt herum rennen, weil sie unwissend sind. Eva nun aber (schliesslich ist Frau die Wurzel des Boesen hoch 2(seltsam nur, dass sie aus dem Mann entspringt... aber das nur am Rande)) isst vom verbotenen Baum und gibt Adam ebenfalls davon zu kosten und dann (Zitat) "and the eyes of them both were opened, and they knew that they were naked; and they sewed fig leaves together and made themselves aprons". Das war dann die Stelle, an der wir alle in schallendes Gelaechter ausbrachen. Don't get me wrong, nicht das ihr jetzt denkt, ich wuerde die Schoepfungsgeschichte in Frage stellen, mal ganz abgesehen von der Nichtexistenz der Hoehlenmenschen, Adams Ausruf, ein Mann soll Vater und Mutter verlassen und Eins werden, mit der Frau, ohne das Vater und Mutter zu diesem Zeitpunkt ueberhaupt existieren und dem massiven Inzest versteht sich. Nun lese ich Artussage, ungefaehr genauso authentisch wie Genesis und die Gebrueder Grimm, allerdings unterhaltsamer. Berichte bei Gelegenheit...

Nach ca einem Jahr ewigem Gedudel von "du und wieviel von deinen Freunden" habe ich immer noch nicht genug und ich frage mich, ob mich das langweilig macht, was ja jetzt eigentlich auch ohne Belang ist. Vorgestern lief es mir zum ersten Mal ueber den Weg, viel mehr lag es mir zum ersten Mal ueber den Weg. Lucy, das von mir getaufte Riesenkaenguruh, ist tot und liegt mit Schwanz zu mir neben der Limestone Avenue, gegenueber einem vielfach Hunde besuchten Park. Nun fragt man sich, woher kam Lucy, wie schaffte sie es, 50% einer vielbefahrenen Zweispurstrasse zu ueberqueren und wie starb Lucy und hinterliess sie ausreichend Schaden am Auto des Uebeltaeters (da faellt mir dann spontan eine aeusserst sensible Liedzeile ein: der Fahrer hat nur leis' gelacht und hat an Fricasse gedacht; aber das nur am Rande) . Ich bin wohl nun privilegiert, jeden Tag Lucys Rottungszustaende zu beobachten; und das nach Mary, der Fledermaus! Aber es gibt eben Dinge, die eine Frau tun muss... Gestern erhielt ich eine Einladung, abends weg zu gehen, was die erste Aktivitaet in 3,5 Wochen gewesen waere. Zu meinem persoenlichen Unglueck wurde diese dan auch gleich wieder zurueck gezogen, als es sich heraus stellte, dass es sich nicht um eine Privatparty sondern Clubbing handelte. Kein mensch kann sich vorstellen, wie oft ich dieses Jahr schon gefragt wurde, ob ich mitkommen wolle und wievielen Autoruecklichtern ich im Anschluss hinterher sah. Es ist doch einmal mehr die augenzwinkernde Ironie des Lebens, 10 Tage vor Abreise aus einem Land, in dem man nichts tun kann, ohne Volljaehrigkeit, volljaehrig zu werden.. So sitze ich meine Wochenenden also alleine hier ab, missmutig und -nun sehr poetisch- als Gefangene meines eigenen Koerpers. Ich hoffe ihr bemitleidet mich ausreichend. .. Ploetzlich, die letzten Tage, werde ich von Kindheitserinnerungen ueberschwemmt -und dann noch nicht mal meinen Eigenen! Man, das ist alles schon ganz schoen lange her, denke ich ploetzlich und ein Tropfen Wehmut mischt sich schweigend unter. Ploetzlich machen alle Abitur und beginnen den Ernst des Lebens, waehrend ich mich hier mit Kadavern und Hundespaziergaengen auseinander setze.. es ist schon eine verrueckte Welt. Besonders eine Geschichte faellt mir immer wieder ein, die ich noch nicht einmal selbst erlebt sondern nur erzaehlt bekommen habe; das muss nun ueber 12 Jahre her sein... Ein sehr guter Freund aus Kindertagen, der mir noch immer erhalten geblieben ist, sollte "ausgeblasene Eier" mit in die Grundschule bringen. Seine Mutter versuchte ihm die Schalen der Eier anzudrehen, aber er beharrte auf dem Inhalt, "dem Ausgeblasenen" und setzte sich auch schliesslich durch, schliesslich hatte die Lehrerin ausdruecklich darum gebeten. Wie er nun also ankam, mit seinem Ausgeblasenen, fuehlte sich die Lehrerin unheimlich verarscht (wir nannten sie den Haber-Geier statt Habermeyer und die Frau hatte gelbe Haare, ganz im Ernst; der wollte man nicht im Dunkeln begegnen) und dachte, dieser Sechsjaehrige haette sich einen wahnsinnig frechen Spass mit ihr erlaubt. Das Ganze endete glaube ich in einem Elterngespraech, in dem sich dann alles klaerte. In jedem Falle kam ich zu dem Schluss, dass Grundschullehrer eine Menge emotionalen Schaden anrichten koennen.. all die traenengefluteten Naechte, weil ich die 7er Reihe nicht auswendig konnte und somit ja ganz sicher sitzen bleiben wuerde; das waren noch Zeiten. Heute schlaegt man sich mit scheinbar Komplexerem herum, aber am Ende ist es doch immer das Gleiche: man moechte am Liebsten irgendwo unterkriechen und warten, bis der Sturm vorueber gezogen ist, was mich meiner Theorie wieder naeher bringt, dass es ein Erwachsenweden so gar nicht gibt, sondern nur unendliche Wiederholung, die im zunehmenden Alter nur etwas entwickelter ist, als beim Kleinkind. Was wir fuehlen ist doch immer wieder das Gleiche, so zum Beispiel nun das Beduerfnis nach einer schoenen heissen Tasse Kaffe...

Gerade sass ich einem Treffen der "Graslandes Freunde" bei, das ist ungefaehr so interessant, wie es klingt. Besonders gefiel mir der Vorschlag, die "Grassland friends" in "Herbland friends" umzubenennen, nur um ganz genau zu sein. ich nehme an die Homepage bekaeme einigen Zuwachs, wenn auch "aus Versehen".. ein Vortrag ueber ein Experiment, bei dem systematisch Quadratmeter von Gras weggebrannt wurden berichtete letztendlich von dem faszinierenden Ergebnis (nach einem Jahr Forschung), dass es eigentlich keinen Unterschied macht, ob man das Ganze abbrennt, oder nicht. Die Pflanzen sind davon ziemlich unbeeintraechtigt. Nach einer weiteren Stunde Vortrag ueber Kuweits Graslaender (keine; dank Besandung und ein par Steinen waechst dort so gut wie ueberhaupt nichts) und 5 Tassen Kaffe fuehlte ich mich dann auch befaehigt, Kuweits Wuesten zu waessern. Nun sitze ich hier und fuehle mich ignorant beim Gedanken, kein Unkrautsexperte sein zu wollen. Von wegen Offenheit! Hiermit gelobe ich dann auch feierlich, mich zu bessern. wo kommen wir denn sonst hin... Walforschungsvorschlag fuer heute: Ist ein Walzahn ein gutes Murmelaufbewahrungsgefaess und sollte Walauge eine Dauerzutat fuer Bloody Mary sein?! ..und noch ein Woody-Zitat fuer die verzweifelten unter uns: Ihr seid nicht allein! "the last time I was in a woman was when I visited the statue of liberty"

Gestern sah ich mal wieder eines der Machwerke des guten alten Woody; dasvon blieb mir folgendes Zitat zwischen den Ribosomen haengen: I grew up in Brooklyn. Nobody in Brooklyn commited suicide. We were all too depressed. ..Ach ja und die Wale natuerlich. Oles Vorschlag hinterliess mich beeindruckt -von den Japanern. Die haben uns an Weisheit halt noch Einiges voraus. Was man so mit einem Wal anfangen kann... mein heutiger Vorschlag ist die wissenschaftlich hochinteressante und hochwichtige Frage: Koennen Wale fliegen?! Dies sollte nach sorgfaeltiger Obduktion von 380 Walen durchaus zu klaeren sein. Die Geheimnisse der Welt moegen im Verborgenen liegen, aber die Japaner sind auf der richtigen Spur!

heute morgen auf dem Weg durch den dichten Nebel (den konnte man schnieden wie Toastbrot- und ich sage euch, im uebertragenen Sinne habe ich da eine Menge weissmehl eingeatmet) schoss es mir ploetzlich in den Kopf: Oh du boese Ironie! Einmal in meinem Leben schaffe ich es, ein Wortspiel zu gebracuhen und dann noch nicht einmal mit Absicht! Nun heisst es sich fragen: masst mein Hirn seltsam an oder ist es seltsam-anmassend?! ich grueble noch immer

Heute morgen, kurz nachdem ich einmal mehr Dank vereistem Bordstein meine Erdverbundenheit demonstrierte, kam mir ploetzlich in den Sinn wie sehr Modebewusstsein das Individuum praegt und beeintraechtigt. In meinem Falle mit der zuvor genannten Fusssohlenabloesung. Selbst wenn man nun also den Stil bewusst boykottieren moechte und sich besten Gewissens eines Paars schaebiger Doc Martens bemaechtigt bleibt man nicht unbelangt von diesem Teufelskreis! Kaum auf der Strasse und ein halbes Stuendchen gelaufen, schon ist das Paar Fuesse ausser Gefecht gesetzt und man muss notgedrungen auf das Paar Adidasturnschuhe zurueck greifen und sich selbst verleugnen, viel mehr, der Mode huldigen. Aber der Mittelweg ist ja nie weit und das Problem mit einem Paar langer Hosen zumindest abgedeckt, womit der genannte Teufelskreis bewiesen waere: Umzu beweisen, dass man sich keinen Deut um Markenkleidung schert, muss eben diese versteckt werden was ja nachdenken ueber Kleidung voraussetzt. Wer mir aus der Misere helfen kann, der melde sich. Weiterhin troetete mir das Radio heute morgen ins Ohr, dass Japan stolz verkuendete, es werde seinen Walfang nun von 210 auf 380 pro Jahr steigern; das Ganze natuerlich "for scientific reasons...research". An dieser Stelle wuerde ich nun gerne Vorschlaege sammeln, was diese "reasons" sein koennten. Mein Vorschlag fuer heute: Wie oft laesst sich ein Waldickdarm um eine Nachttischlampe schlingen?

Hier sind wir, ich und ich und ich, in Canberra am anderen Ende der Welt; ganz ploetzlich ist der Kontakt zur "realen" Welt sehr rar (und wer bezieht schon gern seine Mutter mit ein) und die natuerliche Misantrophie drueckt auf die mentale Blase.. Wo sind sie hin, all die Freunde und Kollegen?! kein Wunder, dass solche geschichten aus meiner Feder fliessen. Doch wo ein Wille ist ist auch eine Nora und wo eine Nora ist ist auch eine hemmungslose Uebertreibung. Aber wer heult nicht gerne, bei -7 Grad Aussentemperatur! Und das nennen die Australien. So bleiben mir statt hautkrebsigen Surferin 4 treue Hundebeine und drei Blasen an den Fusssohlen. Da sag ich Prost zur Unabhaengigkeit!

Eine Erinnerung hat sprachliche Gestalt angenommen und ist laengst mehr als Erinnerung und natuerlich auch weit ueber die Realitaet hinaus gewachsen, trotzdem moechte ich sie einem bestimmten Menschen widmen. Die Geschichte habe ich uebrigens zusammen mit "In the mirror" fuer einen Wettbewerb eingeschickt, bei dem ich keinen Blumentopf gewinnen werde. somit wird die Oeffentlichkeit eben auf anderem wege eingeweiht, hehe As you turned Do you remember this afternoon that we spent together in the park? Sweat was building shiny little pearls over your upper lip, slowly wetting your dried-out mouth. The sky was blue as the sea when we lay on the grass and you collected flower seeds off my apple-green dress and I brushed out beetles, tangled up in your hair. Then you would get up and jump around, making me laugh like a little child seeing a clown’s grimaces. You would climb the old stonewall like a monkey and I would watch the golden sun ball, slowly gliding towards west. It became chilly that afternoon but we pretended it was summer and would not put on our jumpers; you and me and the beetles. Then, this one night, somebody mistook us for a couple and we were laughing and grinning and playing along; paradox, we would call it, silently knowing that it always contained a cheeky little drop of truth that would sneak through and uneven the plain surface. Our eyes met and remained silent for half a lash’s beat before they kept wandering. Like blindfolded children, we were stumbling around in the dark, groping for our ways. Maybe we knew more than we thought we did. And this one night, do you remember? I was at this party, calling you and you came all the way and we walked up the hill in silence, away from them. The grass blades were wet and slippery, swaying between our bare toes as we lay down and looked up into the sky, as if searching for something that wasn’t there, gray clouds passing like ghostly shadows of an indistinct future. I may have kissed you that night and it may have made all the difference as your arm was wrapped around my shoulder and my nose pressed against your chest. It may have made all the difference. Later on this night we would walk down this empty street, people talking, taking space between us, highlighting our silence. We would keep our eyes low, sitting down on the pavement, watching the unlucky hitchhiker on a street without cars in the middle of the night, finally talking. Avoiding or getting caught up in each other’s eyes, we were like ashamed five-year olds, out feet scraping the ground. We talked and you asked me about opera, all of a sudden, knowing my passion. You made me stand on a manhole cover and we pretended it was my little stage and I sang- in the middle of the night in the middle of the street, just a couple of friends watching with only the stars as our witnesses. I was too embarrassed to continue, stopped after a couple of words and I remember you sitting on the ground in your old shoes and too short jeans, looking at me, moving your head slightly to the right while narrowing your eyes, barely a movement at all. It was later that you told me that you thought it was special and one day, you’d like to hear me singing the whole piece, somewhere; and when you talked, little wrinkles spread around your eyes, like rivers. Thinking back, the memory of that night feels like salt in an open wound, appearing like a razor blade that is buried deep down inside me, circling. I don’t even know when it was that we saw each other for the last time. Your words were as sharp as needle strikes; deep-frying me, you were growing ice flowers in the air, more prick than bloom. We knew the old game, you turning the blade in my intestines and me, defenseless, still trying. We went on and on and maybe missed the turns all along. Maybe there were no options anyway and it was meant to be too late right from the beginning up to the end. But I can still feel the aggression vibrating in the air, emotions all tangled up and buried, somewhere beneath all the layers and the desperate feeling that it was all wrong. I should have known. Numbness fills my limbs, slowly spreading its ugly fingers, paralyzing me. Dumb and numb, confused and ugly, that is how I feel, suddenly remembering all those things, adding up a thousand questions in a quarter of a second, a thousand things to tell. Suddenly, all I remember are the unimportant, tiny things and I become angry with you because of the White Russian at your place that you promised me. I’m mad at you, mad. Most people tell me I shouldn’t, that I should feel sorry for you and the desperation you must have felt but I don’t. I sit on the bench outside the house, hitting my guitar, no one else to blame; singing, beating the words out of my body, like the strokes of a whip. I call you an idiot and an asshole for your carelessness; disgusted, by you and by myself. Feeling angry, sick and helpless, so helpless, I’m thinking the same thoughts over and over again. It doesn’t feel real, not sad, and not dark, only strange, foreign. Somehow, I’m light as a feather, as if the next wind might just blow me off my feet and drag me away. I can’t help thinking how weak and egoistic you are, judging you for giving up, throwing it all away, just like that. Eventually it darkens and I’m sitting alone on my bench, embracing the guitar like an old memory, as if it could never fly away when I just hold on to it. On a cold but sunny afternoon, a girl walked down the street, turning left behind the flowerbeds, keeping her head down, rubbing her gloved fingers. The birds were returning in swarms, heading north as shrieking black dots high over her head. Last week’s frost had disappeared over one night and suddenly revealed thousands upon thousands of crocus buds which had been buried under frozen layers of crisp snow for weeks, noisily broken by children’s boots and enthusiastically dragged sledges. Spring was coming and the world was new and innocent again; all sins washed away by heavy autumn rains and old memories cleaned of all bitterness by winter air, blowing away the dust and coming through every pore like a long expected and needed healing power. The silence, holding its single frozen note in the cold was finally broken by spring that made all flowers pop open in a day, the world suddenly in bloom and filled up with all sorts of smells, newborn and forgiving. It was late afternoon when the girl crossed the road and went through the old rusty gate, standing still for a moment and observing the gossiping swarms of cranes, circling in the sky. Moving on, they lectured, and she gave a nod, barely perceptible, just as she started to climb the stairs up to the local cemetery. “There was a girl in the graveyard today”, the old gardener Jack tells the priest, unconsciously turning the shovel in his hands, “she didn’t have any respect for the dead”, but it doesn’t sound quite right the moment he hears himself saying it out loud. Jack himself was some rows away from where she stayed, doing the flowers on old Henry’s. But he remembers her passing by, even before she started to behave the way she did. He remembers her because of the way she smiled, an unusual way, in the midst of all this grief and pain, all these weeping old women, making their way up here every day to visit their relative’s graves for some time, fresh flowers between their clammy fingers. This girl was clearly only passing through, he thought, the way she smiled. Five minutes later however, Jack found himself unable to get the weeds out of the ground and went to get a shovel. He was a committed gardener and not the type that gave up easily, even though he had worked on those weeds for quite some time. In fact, he had been away for a couple of weeks, in hospital because of his bad hip, and his replacement had done a poor job, using the frozen ground as an excuse. The roots seemed to have spread and connected underground so it seemed impossible to get them out without doing further damage to the flowers. He went and walked to the storage shed, looking up without even meaning to, and saw the girl from a distance. She was lifting a glass in front of a grave as if to say “cheers”, than drinking, slowly. When he took a closer look, he saw that there was a second glass that was placed on the gravestone and he would find it there later on when the girl had gone, filled to the brim. Jack of course tells the priest that he emptied the glass’s content into the toilet but he actually poured half of it onto the flowerbed next to the grave and then decided to at least give it a try, it couldn’t be so bad, could it? He finally shrugged, watching the girl drinking and thought he might just leave it at that since she wasn’t offending anyone, but another five minutes later, she caught his attention again. He already knew that it would be her, even though he couldn’t see her. There are some things that you can just tell. He got up and moved towards her as quickly as he could but his hip was still pretty bad and he hobbled along, minutes passing, cursing his age as he did so often these days. For some reason, there was always balance in the world. As a young boy, strong, filled with hope and thirsty for life, he hadn’t known a thing; now, at the age of sixty-two, he had seen the world but his body gave up on him. Frowning over these thoughts that appeared to him in equal parts ironic and yet unavoidable, he came closer. He realized that the girl was singing an opera, and in some kind of way, it was a pity to interrupt, Jack thought. There was a certain peculiarity, a certain feeling that hit him by surprise and made him stop walking, trying to shake of this sudden sentimentality he felt. This was a graveyard, a place of silence and prayer, he thought angrily and with indignation that he knew was stronger than it would have been sensible, let alone appropriate. Wrestling down the irrationality that struck him, he would make it his personal duty to protect the peace that lay over the graveyard; the peace that was something that fitted in his mind scheme, something that worked for him in this world that he could not understand anymore. As he hadn’t been real good for anything in his life, he’d do at least his best in this job and this place that one day would be the last resting place of his mortal remains, too. When he finally arrived at a spot from where he had a clear view at the grave, the girl had already fallen silent, remaining in her position for a second or two. She was silently looking at the grave, then abruptly turning and walking away. The cranes took off from where they had rested, spreading their wings majestically. It was a long flight, a long and difficult way until they would finally arrive at their destination, a place to stay, a place called home. Jack shook his head, long and thoughtfully, as he hobbled off. There were clearly more things to the world than simple reproduction, somewhere in between, a place that he could not explain, not even fully imagine. There were things he could neither name nor understand, things that were probably not for him anyway, but when they were happening, he should let them pass, so much he knew. He might not understand them but maybe that wasn’t even important when he could grasp a tiny spark of these spirits, every now and then.

I can see through time it runs slowly but rapidly destroys everything a thoughtful tree, standing like a quotation mark each tree plays a different part in time whispering while their roots spread through the earth earth as a measure of time, beginning like a blooming flower in spring, fading like a candle burning to the end of the wick

In the mirror 4.54pm Blue-silvery light from over the mirror; the walls move closer, whispering. There is a smoke-stained sign over the door, “unisex”. The towel. The window. An ashtray. Close, too close, strangling her. The tap erupts fountains of water, bubbling and gurgling as if in deadly pain, as if it was about something. Or nothing, everything. Her hands move mechanically, covered in soap, little dirty bubbles that look like boils; as if it makes them dirty, dirtier. Dirt. It is everywhere. Everything is so unclean that she needs to wash, wash, wash; hold on to it, tight. She can’t drown in this mud if she just holds on to herself, clean, clean; in the biggest letters, capital. She can feel the sweat, cold as ice, building up in her neck, dropping. It is disgusting, all cold. She can’t perceive it anymore, her blue hands, her frozen insides. Scar tissue, outside and inside, embraces the cold, inviting the emptiness and silence in to fill the space and muffle up every sound that might come through this thick fog. She doesn’t feel the cold, the unhealthy colour crawling up her arms, nearly touching the bony elbows; but now, in the light… She wants to scrub her hands, scrub away their dry surface, their ugliness, until she can find something pure underneath, clean it, clean herself. All is so dirty. A weeping screech; the tap keeps dripping, seeking attention. Biting into her knuckle, just to feel the pain rise, she tastes blood but she can’t reach herself; she is so far gone, everything locked deep down inside, drawn away from her. All there is now is the tap’s dropping and the mad hammering in her head, tightening her chest; she can barely breathe. Dizzy, she leans against the yellow wall, smoke-stained. Looking down, she can’t find anything to hold on to, nothing but bones and skin, ready to tear apart, so tight. There is no substance underneath, there is nothing left. The eyes of a frightened deer in the mirror, big and round and trusty like the full moon, scream in her face. It hurts to look at them; they are deadly. Following the channel to the inside, she blinks, but there is nothing, nothing at all behind those curtains, those terrified eyes, animalistic. Emptiness. Her head keeps hammering as her hands clench around the washbasin, her knuckles turning from blue to white. A drop of blood is drying on the back of her hand, like a lizard in the sun. She stares into the mirror, taking in this immediate vacuum of time and space, screaming silence, her scarred arms even tighter then the rest of her skin. How much she needs a blade, right now. The urge for warmth; to feel the heat breaking out of her, bringing the blurry picture back in focus. She can feel every scar, every single one of them. Always. “Who are you”, she whispers, staring at those eyes in the mirror, nearly screaming, “who are you?” 5.13pm He locks the door, just to find the knob stained and greasy. The black briefcase is rocking back and forwards in his hand as he hurries along the bright corridor. He is slightly late because of Sheila- again. She disappeared three weeks ago and this time it seems, for good. Normally, they always found her half-consciously lying in some corner after a couple of days, more drugs in her veins than her anorexic-thin body could possibly take. But eventually, there is no way around it. Even though she is bloody sixteen years old and you would have thought she might be able to look after herself for a bit. Twenty years between them, twenty years that should make him superior, supposedly she should be an adult, able to make decisions, knowing what to do and still, he is lost, a blank, as far as she is concerned. Somebody might have seen her, the officer said on the phone and again, it took so long to deliver this tiny piece of information that Michael is late. He should have been in Sundale’s hotel room fifteen minutes ago. It still feels strange, sometimes even humiliating, this guy-his boss- being thirteen years younger than Michael himself, but that is how it goes in the company; whoever is related to somebody in a high position or has a lot of money to donate is immediately walking on red carpet meanwhile Miss Smith, his colleague, and him, who are working so much harder than the others, will never reach an important position, so much is for sure; she because she is a woman and he because he doesn’t have the vibe of success around him. In fact, he looks like a loser even though he has more brains than all of the big shots together. Sometimes he wishes mum was still around. She had this incredible calm around her that made him relax a bit so this desperation and panic that now sometimes suddenly evolves in him, making him dizzy, would not even get a chance. She was so strong, being left twice by the guys that got her pregnant she never complained and he didn’t see her cry once. Michael had never met his father nor did he know who he was. Then there is the situation with Sheila, of course. If just mum were here, everything would be all right straight away. She always knew what to do with Michael himself, it would be just the same with his sister. The hotel’s foyer is noisy and impersonal; he is searching the seats with his eyes. There’s a group of noisy adolescents passing by; something like violence lies in the air, he can’t completely say what it is. Finally he sees Miss Smith who is as reliable as usual, sitting with her knees pressed together, reading. He can’t take his eyes off her lips, coloured in bright red. They’ll walk up to the hotel together and even though their lateness will be an issue, it is all only half as bad with her at his side. If he weren’t so tangled up in his private life, Sheila’s absence and life in general, he would give her a closer look. After all this time, these endless hours of boring and exhausting work, she hasn’t let him down once; she’s a brick. Next to Miss Smith who gets up, shyly smiling at him, certainly aware of the time, sits an old lady. She’s knitting, a steaming cup of coffee next to her. His eyes flicker to the man on Miss Smith’s left who’s got a slight coffee stain on his trousers. Miss Smith is like the peacekeeper, dividing the warring parties. The man is holding on to a suitcase just like Michael’s meanwhile smoking one cigarette after another. His face looks familiar in some kind of way but Michael just can’t place it and is too busy hurrying up anyway. If he’d just take a closer look, he would recognize the face for sure. Maybe he wouldn’t have thought about his lateness anymore if he had known that it was Mortenson himself, waiting for his plane, sitting next to Miss Smith by accident. Frederic Mortenson, tomorrow’s client and today’s topic before the plane takes off. He is the one Mr Sundale (more by presence than actual participation; but of course he’ll be congratulated in the end for “his incredible, unselfish effort”), Miss Smith and Michael himself have prepared for over the last weeks; the one they will have to convince about their products tomorrow morning, nine o’clock. Maybe Michael wouldn’t have cared about his lateness anymore if he had realized that looking at that man was like looking in a mirror. And maybe, if Michael wouldn’t have been too busy inventing a reason for his lateness that seemed plausible, he would have seen Sheila, cowering in the corner next to the toilet, staring at her blood-encrusted hands that she just couldn’t get clean. And maybe, if he hadn’t been so lost in thoughts, he would have wondered later on why Sundale was so atypically relaxed about their lateness and gave Miss Smith that greasy smile of his that was somehow indiscreet and intimidating at the same time. If Michael only would have said one word to Miss Smith, just something; maybe about Sundale in general since they equally disliked him, Miss Smith and him, or how her presence was like a light in the darkness for him. He might have found out the whole story, which may have changed just about everything.
